titleStmt.title: Protocol for measuring the benefits of exergames on executive functions under depression through a randomized multi-arm controlled experiment

analytic.title: Protocol for measuring the benefits of exergames on executive functions under depression through a randomized multi-arm controlled experiment

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: (The article is Open Access and everyone can read and download it for free) Journal: Exploration of Neuroscience (indexed by DOAJ, the Directory of open access journals, an index of high-quality, open-access, peer-review journals).

div.p: are experiencing increasing levels of sadness, worry and anxiety [1,2]. Depressive disorders are estimated to affect 300 million people worldwide [3]. In the United States, Spain, Austria, Portugal and Australia, depression has estimated prevalence rates of approximately 5% [4]. And recent epidemiological studies have shown a significant increase in depression, anxiety, and other psychological conditions [5][6][7].

Depression is characterized by emotional problems, cognitive alterations, and social and behavioral changes. Among them, we can mention depressed mood, hopelessness, a decreased interest in usual activities, fatigue, rumination, regular thoughts of death and suicide, changes in appetite, and difficulty concentrating. The cognitive alterations associated with depression are frequently ignored, and they are not evaluated at the beginning or after the remission of the affective symptoms.

When the affective alterations remit, it is assumed that the psychological condition 4 / 44 has been overcome. However, it has been reported that cognitive deficits continue after remission, compromising the lives of people and having an impact on societies, work performance and economy [11][12][13].

The current work focused on the development of a randomized controlled trial to assess how the cognitive domains compromised in people suffering from depression can benefit from a psychological intervention, consisting of an exergame, a video game that integrates cognitive and psychomotor stimulation.
Previous studies conducted in psychology have tried to use classical cognitive stimulation programs in people with diverse conditions, showing positive effects.

During recent decades, computational programs have been implemented as easyaccess alternatives, but due to problems with motivation, engagement, and adherence to the intervention, new cognitive programs based on video games have recently raised [14].

Previous research assessed whether video games have a global positive effect on depression, but there are no studies systematically revising specific contributions of video games to cognitive domains altered in depression [15]. In addition, studies considering the effects of video games on general depressive symptomatology show moderate benefits, but there is a lack of consensus regarding the positive effects of these programs because of issues concerning the methodology used [16].

Using exergames with sound methods may allow to overcome previous limitations and reach targeted effects. Physical training has been demonstrated to have a positive effect on cognition in people suffering from depression [17], and multidomain training (combining cognitive and physical stimulation) has shown higher effects than unidomain interventions [18].

As depression is characterized by a decrease in energy and psychomotor functioning [19], and physical training could be excessively demanding for a person suffering 5 / 44 from depression, implementing a program that combines cognitive stimulation through games with moderate physical activity (exergames) may be a better suited novel approach.
Studies analyzing the effects of exergames on depression are scarce and crosssectional; they do not focus on the cognitive impairment associated with depression.

Moreover, these studies do not include an active control group that trains in similar conditions as the intervention group, and they do not measure the placebo effects depending on previous experience, expectations, motivation, and engagement, so it is difficult to accurately ascertain the effects of the programs [20].
In the present publication, we describe the procedure to assess how executive functions (EFs) could benefit from exergames under depressive conditions.
EFs are related to the ability to organize information, planning, reasoning, decision making and problem solving. These functions are essential in our daily life activities.

They are complex cognitive abilities that include cognitive domains, subdomains, and different components, such as executive attention, working memory, cognitive control, inhibition, cognitive flexibility, updating or shifting.

When EFs are compromised, people show problems regarding their ability to adapt to a new situation or condition, which requires a different mind setting. This ability is associated with cognitive flexibility, cognitive control, inhibition, and updating. In those cases, we can register and measure how people with these deficits commit more errors, specifically perseverative errors. It is, they experience difficulties shifting their minds to a new rule, and they continue responding to a previous rule, using inadequate planning strategies, presenting difficulty in choosing the adequate response, and solving the problem.

Experimental and review studies show that depression is associated with an impairment in EFs. Deficits are related to the domain of shifting or switching between 6 / 44 tasks, a dysfunction in the ability of inhibition (cease actions or thoughts that are no longer useful), or a broad impairment of EFs in depressed individuals [21][22][23]
Experimental Task to Measure Executive Functions:

div.head: WCST
div.p: In this randomized controlled experiment, the effects of exergames on executive functions are measured by using a classical experimental task: the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) [24][25][26], which consists of classifying a card following changing rules according to three different criteria: matching the color, the shape, or the number of symbols.

Therefore, the screen shows a card; each card can present a different number of symbols (one, two, three or four symbols) with different colors (red, blue, yellow, or green) and shapes (circle, cross, triangle, or star), but all the symbols in the card have the same shape and color, i.e., two green stars ( Figure 1).

Then, the participant must choose from a group of four cards presented at the same time on the screen. The participant does not know the criteria to classify the principal card and must infer it by trying, receiving positive or negative feedback, and adjusting the response. After several trials using the same classification rule, it can change

div.head: Neuroscientific Approach: Depression and Measures of WCST
div.p: From the cognitive neuroscientist perspective, the WCST is a tool that has been extensively used to assess damage and deficits associated with the frontal lobes [35].

Frontal lobes play a fundamental role in filtering and selecting information that will be later processed and integrated in other associative brain areas. Thus, frontal lobes have been related to EFs or the ability to organize information, plan, make decisions, inhibit, control cognition, shift, solve problems and so on [36,37].

Functional neuroimaging studies show patterns of abnormal brain activation in depressed subjects at different regions: the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, superior temporal cortex, cingulate cortex, insula, caudate, thalamus, hippocampus, and parahippocampal gyrus, among others. Depending on the experimental task and the valence of the task, registrations can show hypoactivity or hyperactivity of these brain networks [38].

From a structural approach, young and older adults suffering from depression show smaller gray-matter volumes relative to controls in the frontal-limbic regions: the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate, cerebellar, temporal, and parietal regions [39][40][41]. Meanwhile, reduced white matter was also observed in the frontal-limbic circuit, extending from the genu of the corpus callosum to the inferior fasciculus and posterior thalamic radiation [42,43]. The WCST has been used to explore the electrophysiological components associated with executive functions and executive attention [45][46][47]. shown that people suffering from depression exhibit decreased P300 amplitudes and prolonged latency [48][49][50][51].
Other brain components have been associated with EFs. There are several N1

subcomponents. The lateral occipital visual N1 subcomponent seems to be related to attention and discriminative processing [52][53][54]. In addition, some studies have found a significant correlation between target-locked N100 and information processing P300. These authors hypothesize that a lower amplitude of N100 could be associated with a dysfunction in attention and perception, affecting later cognitive processes linked to updating of the latest information in working memory [55].

Moreover, attention ability seems to be related to shifting [56]. Indeed, some researchers have demonstrated using the WCST that P3b modulation can be attributed not only to the selection or storage of sensory stimuli but also to an internal shift in the perceptual rule that is being used to sort the cards [47].

Under depressive conditions, the N1 component helps to differentiate between depressive and healthy participants. Showing higher latency and lower amplitude in N1 under depressive conditions [50,[57][58][59].
Taking into consideration the auditory sensory response, mismatch negativity (MMN)

is registered when subjects are exposed to identical stimuli with occasional mismatching stimuli (e.g., a sequence of 800-Hz tones and occasional 1200-Hz tones [46]. However, further research is needed.

div.head: Data acquisition
div.p: As this experiment is part of a project that measures diverse cognitive functions, the order of presentation of the tasks, including the WCST, will be counterbalanced across subjects. Indeed, all the methodological designs of the outcome measures will be constructed using the rules of counterbalancing and stimulus rotation. In addition, response keys will be counterbalanced across conditions.

WCST will be programmed with E-Prime 2.0 (Psychology Software Tools Inc., Pittsburgh, PA, USA), and the statistical analyses of the behavioral and electrophysiological results will be conducted with different data-analysis software.

After screening, participants will be randomized into three groups. Then, preevaluation will take place, collecting data about the primary and secondary outcomes. Thereafter, the intervention will be developed over a period of eight weeks, with two sessions per week, for a total of 40-50 minutes per session. After intervention, we will perform the postevaluation. Three months after finishing the intervention, we will measure the effects of the follow-up through the final assessment.

div.head: Stimuli
div.p: We will use a computerized version of WCST that is a part of the stimulus In each trial, a single choice card (principal card) will be presented at the bottom right corner of the screen, and the participant will need to match it to one of the four reference cards that appear in the upper part of the screen (Figure 2). After the response, written positive or negative feedback ("right" or "wrong") will be provided depending on whether the matching was correct or incorrect. The highlighted feedback will appear on the left part of the screen, and the interval between feedback offset and the next WCST trial will vary randomly between 2 and 3 s. Then, a new trial will start.

Participants will use a response panel with four buttons aligned. The far-left button corresponds to the reference card on the far left of the screen, the far-right button corresponds to the reference card on the far right on the screen, and so forth. Subjects must use their thumbs to respond.

To ensure that the participants understood the instructions, they will practice for approximately five minutes. Then, the formal experiment will start. It consists of eighteen series. As we have mentioned before, the series varies randomly between six and nine trials. The average duration of the task will be approximately 20 minutes.

div.head: ERPs recording
div.p: Continuous electroencephalograph activity will be recorded while performing the WCST using a NuAmps amplifier (Neuroscan Inc.). Testing will take place in an electrically shielded, quiet, and dimly illuminated room. To record brain activity, we will use a 34-channel elasticized Quik-Cap with Ag/AgCl sintered electrodes (Neuroscan Inc.), positioned according to the extended 10-20 system [73], and referenced to linked mastoids (A1, A2). Participants will be grounded to the AFz electrode, and signals will be bandpass filtered (0.1-70 Hz), notch filtered (50 Hz) and
amplified at a sampling rate of 250 Hz.

The electrooculogram (EOG) will also be recorded to correct the influence of ocular artifacts. Vertical and horizontal electrooculograms will be recorded in two bipolar channels. Eye blinks and vertical eye movements will be monitored via electrodes located below and on the supraorbital ridge of the left eye. Horizontal artifacts will be monitored via electrodes on the outer canthus of each eye. The existence of blinks and other ocular movements will not be a criterion for epoch rejection. These artifacts will be eliminated using Independent Component Analysis (ICA) decomposition [74][75][76][77].

After ICA decomposition, artifact components will be removed by inspection of their scalp topography and spectral power [78]. EOG correction and muscle or movement artifacts will be discarded. Those trials exceeding EEG amplitudes of ± 75 mV at any active electrode or response latencies longer than 4 seconds will also be discarded.
Only artifact-free epochs will be selected for average.

After filtering, signals will be extracted in epochs ranging from -200 to 1000 ms after feedback onset. Then, the extracted epochs will be averaged in each condition for analysis. Analysis will be performed using the EEGLAB toolbox [79] and ERPLAB plugin for EEGLAB [80], both running under the MATLAB environment (The MathWorks Inc.)

div.head: Training Intervention
div.p: The intervention group will train with an exergame. We will use an adapted version of ExerCube by Sphery Ltd. [81]. After studying diverse possibilities, we choose this program because it provides simultaneous physical and cognitive training through video games in an immersive gaming environment, and it allows the user to adapt the intensity and physical demand from moderate to high intensity, which is especially 16 / 44 important for people suffering from depression [82]. We will use a combination of training programs provided by ExerCube (Racer, Roboshop, Beat Squash, Fight the Dome, and ExergG).

The training regime will consist of 40-50 min sessions, two sessions per week, for a total of eight weeks of individual training. We use a training regime that is not too long to avoid loss of motivation and attrition.

On the other hand, the active control group will train in similar conditions as the experimental group, but with an intervention program different from an exergame. In this case, participants will practice with adapted cognitive video games, or brain training designed to improve mental performance. Participants will play short brain games designed by Lumosity, a commercial platform (http://www.lumosity.com/).

The selection of games per day will be random, and participants will play individually for 40-50 minutes per session, two sessions per week for a total of eight weeks in a similar setting as the experimental group.
Finally, the passive control group will be a wait-list group.

div.head: Study design
div.p: The present experiment measures how exergames can have a positive effect specifically on EFs in people suffering from depression.

The experiment is a three-arm parallel-group randomized study. We will compare three different interventions (training with an exergame, training with a cognitive game, and a wait-list condition) by randomizing participants to each group with equal probability. To randomly classify the participants into three groups, we will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined blocks. The random number list used to create these three blocks will be created using the web applications available at http://random.org.

Moreover, this experiment is a single-blind design, where participants will be blind to the intervention, but researchers will not be blind to intervention allocation. In addition, it is a longitudinal study with a pretest, intervention, posttest, and 3-month follow-up. All procedures must be approved by a certified scientific board, and the participants must provide written informed consent to be considered for the present experiment.

div.head: Eligibility and exclusion criteria
div.p: All the members in a population between 20 and 60 years old will have the same chance to be selected for this study; participants will be volunteers, and they will be recruited by media advertisements, posters, brochures, and flyers. We will control the sociodemographic variables depending on education, socioeconomic status, participant sex, work status, ethnicity, and age. Prevalence studies have reported that women are frequently at a higher risk of depression than men, but recently, dominance analysis has shown that the variation in the prevalence of depression seems to be explained by similar factors in women and men [83]. To control these effects, we will ensure the proportional gender ratio and the gender balance, and we will analyze the data in a gender-sensitive way.

Participants suffering from depression with comorbidities (bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsion disorder, neurological disorder, or traumatic brain injury) will be excluded. Another exclusion criteria will be <20/60 vision with or without correction, inability to complete the activities, or communication problems. The current use of any antidepressant medication did not function as an exclusionary criterion.

The inclusion and exclusion criteria for persons suffering from depression will be validated by a professional (psychologist) through an interview and the use of reliable and valid psychological assessment tools.

div.head: Beck Depression Inventory-Second Edition (BDI-II)
div.p: We will use the Beck Depression Inventory-Second Edition [84] to measure the severity of depression. It consists of twenty-one items. Each item is scored on a Likert-type scale ranging from 0 to 3 (e.g., "0 = I do not feel sad, 1 = I feel sad, 2 = I am sad all the time and I can't snap out of it, 3 = I am so sad and unhappy that I can't stand it."). The score considered for inclusion criteria were depression (≥ 28 points on

div.head: BDI-II).
div.p: The test has been adapted to Spain (BDI-IA; [85]; BDI-II; [86]). The adaptation of the

div.head: Sample size
div.p: To calculate the value of a sufficient sample size, we have conducted a priori power analysis using the software G-Power 3.1.9.7 [87,88]. The power of a test estimates the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. We calculated the sample size using a model for differences between three groups based on analysis of variance, using an alpha of 0.05, a power of 0.80, and a large effect size (f = 0.40) [89,90]. The result obtained was a total sample size of at least 144 subjects for ten primary outcomes and three secondary outcomes, or approximately fifty participants per group (Figure 3) 20 / 44

We also plan to perform analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) to compare posttest scores across conditions while controlling for pretest scores, so we calculated the sample size for the three groups by conducting a priori power analysis (compute needed sample size, given alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80, and effect size f = 0.40), using ANCOVA fixed effects, main effects, and interactions as statistical tests. In this case,
we obtained a sample size of sixty-five participants (Figure 4).

Thus, we conclude that a total sample size between 75 and 150 subjects, or between 50 and 60 participants per group, is required to have 80% power to show the cognitive benefits of exergames over placebo conditions in terms of EFs measured through the WCST.

div.head: Effects of exergame training on executive functions: Behavioral Analysis
div.p: With the WCST, we will collect information about the outputs previously enumerated and described (Table 1, Additional file 1), where there are ten primary measures associated with EFs or the ability to organize information, manipulate it, adapt to new situations, make decisions, and solve problems. These measures will be collected using the WCST at three different moments: before the intervention, after the intervention, and three months after finishing the intervention.

We want to assess whether there is a difference in performance after the intervention, and 3-months later, for each group and primary outcome (in terms of correct responses, errors, and reaction times).
Moreover, we want to analyze whether the results of each group in the preassessment could be related to other results.

Finally, we will measure the differences among groups, comparing the experimental group's performance and the control groups' performance before, after the training, and 3 months after finishing the intervention.

To do so, mixed Analysis of variance (ANOVAs) with 3 groups (experimental, active control, and passive control) as a between-subjects factor and 3 assessment sessions (before training, after training, and 3-month follow-up) as the within-subjects factor will be performed for each primary outcome to check whether there is a significant difference between the groups and sessions for each WCST measure. The effect size will be calculated using the partial Eta squared (ηp2) to solve the problem relating to population variance overestimation, where a value less than 0.01 will be considered trivial, a value of 0.01 will be considered small, a value equal to 0.06 will represent a medium effect, and a partial Eta squared of 0.14 will be considered a large effect. We will use post hoc pairwise comparisons to analyze where the differences occur. In all analyses, we will use an alpha of 0.05, and all statistical tests will be Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons.

Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) is considered a more appropriate method than change from baseline to enhance the statistical power when the groups have equivalent designs in randomized studies [91]. Thus, we will perform ANOVAs to analyze the main effects and interactions between groups and within sessions, and we

will also perform ANCOVAs to analyze the differences between groups in all the outcomes, using as covariates the pretest scores for those measures, if the needed assumptions are met (the assumption of no relationship between the intersubjects factor (group), and the covariates (ps > 0.05), and the equality of slopes (ps > 0.05)).

Finally, we would like to state that outliers will be reported, but they will not be included in the analyses to avoid the influence of these measures on the main effects and interactions. In some cases, we plan to assess outliers by searching for confidence intervals (CIs) that fell outside the limits of the effect size with 95% CIs. In other cases, we will explore the data-removing trials with a cutoff of 2.5 standard deviations (SD) from the mean [92].

div.head: Effects of exergame training on executive functions: Electrophysiological Analysis
div.p: To We also plan to analyze the N100 subcomponents linked to discrimination processing of information and P300. According to previous studies, a lower amplitude of N100
could be associated with a dysfunction in attention and perception related to the updating of new information and working memory. Under depressive conditions, N1
shows higher latency and lower amplitude.
Moreover, we wanted to explore the relationship between N1 and P200 before and

div.head: Statistical analysis of electrophysiological data
div.p: To explore the effects of Exergames on EFs under depression in terms of brain activity, we will perform several statistical analyses with the brain data collected while performing the WCST.

We will perform mixed ANOVAs to compare the latency and amplitude of the After that, we will compare the differences in brain activity between the three groups at pretest and posttest. Finally, we will analyze the brain activity comparing the three groups at the three given time points.

To control the signal-to-noise ratio, for reaction times (RTs), we will adapt to the task an interval window of 200 ms and 1500 ms to exclude outliers. RTs faster than 200 ms and slower than 1500 ms could be related to distraction according to previous research. Therefore, they will be excluded from the RTs analysis. Moreover, we plan to control the outliers by searching for CIs that fell outside the limits of the effect size with 95% CIs or exploring the data and removing trials with a cutoff of 2.5% SD from the mean [92].
Significant effects will be set at p < 0.05, and we will use post hoc pairwise comparisons to analyze where the differences occur, where all statistical tests will be

Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons. In addition, the effect size will be calculated using the partial Eta squared (ηp2) to solve the problem relating to population variance overestimation, where a value less than 0.01 will be considered trivial, a value of 0.01 will be considered small, a value equal to 0.06 will represent a medium effect, and a partial Eta squared of 0.14 will be considered a large effect.

div.head: Secondary outcomes and analysis
div.p: The control of Placebo's effect depending on the intervention's expectations, motivation and engagement is an important issue in cognitive training [93][94][95].

Therefore, to explore whether these variables account for possible training-related improvements, participants will report their expectations before and after evaluation using a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = the results will be much worse, 3 = there will 26 / 44 not be any change, 5 = the results will be much better). Moreover, they will provide information about their motivation and engagement during training using a similar 5point Likert-type scale (1 = not motivated to 5 = extremely motivated; 1 = not engaged to 5 = extremely immersed).

The reliability of the expectations scale has been previously calculated by combining the items in a global index and computing Cronbach's α. The results showed a reliability of 0.64 for expectations [96]. In addition, some researchers have adapted similar questionnaires [93] producing the expectation assessment scale and analyzing the psychometric properties [97]. They obtained an internal consistency of 0.87.
Regarding the motivation and engagement scales, we will use questionnaires based in other studies that did not report validity coefficients [92,96,98].

Regarding the data analysis, mixed measures ANOVAs with three groups (experimental group, active control group, passive control group) x 2 sessions (pre, post) will be conducted separately for motivation, engagement, and expectations. Post hoc pairwise comparisons will account for the differences. In all analyses, we will use an alpha of 0.05, and all statistical tests will be Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons. In addition, the effect size will be calculated using the partial Eta squared to solve the problem relating to population variance overestimation, where a value less than 0.01 will be considered trivial, a value of 0.01 will be considered small, a value equal to 0.06 will represent a medium effect, and a partial Eta squared of 0.14 will be considered a large effect.

div.head: Expected results
div.p: This randomized experiment aims to measure how exergames can have a positive effect specifically on EFs in people suffering from depression. It is a three-arm parallel-group randomized study, where we compare three different interventions (training with an exergame, training with a cognitive game, and a wait-list condition).

For the experimental group, we will use an adapted version of ExerCube by Sphery Ltd. [81], which provides simultaneous physical and cognitive training and allows the user to adapt the intensity and physical demand from moderate to high intensity, which is especially important for people suffering from depression [82]. In addition, the active control group will train in similar conditions as the experimental group, playing short brain games designed by Lumosity, a commercial platform (http://www.lumosity.com/). And the passive control group will be a wait-list group.

To our knowledge, previous research assessed whether video games have a global positive effect on depression, but there are no studies analyzing specific contributions of video games to cognitive domains altered in depression with a special concern about the quality of the methodology used. Besides, we collect brain activity to analyze the biological and neuropsychological substrate of the cognitive and behavioral changes after the different interventions, what has not been done before.

Another strength of this study is not only to evaluate the immediate effects of the distinct interventions, but also the effect of time on the learning process, after three months of finishing the interventions.

Once analyzing and comparing the WCST performance of the three groups at three time points in terms of cognitive-behavioral responses and brain activity, controlling for placebo effect dependent of expectations, engagement, and motivation, we expect the experimental group benefits differentially in terms of EFs.
Conclusively, exploring the effects of exergames on cognition in participants with

figure.head: 3 / 44 Introduction
figure.figDesc: Before starting, it is important to note that the present publication refers to one experiment of the study entitled "Mudgame", which analyze the benefits of exergames on diverse cognitive domains under depression [ClinicalTrials.gov ID: NCT06536530]. In this article we specifically focus on the effects of exergames on EFs under depression. During recent decades, societies have improved their efforts to build sustainable societies where people can experience wellbeing and happiness. Nonetheless, people

Psychotherapeutic interventions have shown positive effects and remission of the affective alterations in depression; however, major depressive disorder and other depressive conditions are characterized not only by affective-related problems but also by a cognitive decline that affects mental functions, such as attention, memory, learning, process of information, language and communication, decision making, and psychomotor functions [8-10].

figure.head: 7 / 44 without
figure.figDesc: notice, and the participant again will readjust the response to determine the new criteria (Figure 2)

Cognitive set-shifting is associated with changes in different brain areas. The distribution of P300 is frontal, parietal, and central, and larger P300 (P3b) amplitudes are associated with set-shifting and memory update. Different experimental designs can be used to study the subcomponents of P3, including P3a and P3b. The P3b component has a centro-parietal scalp distribution, occurs approximately 300-500 ms after the target stimulus and is related to the allocation of attentional resources, working memory operations, and the decisionmaking process. P3b reflects top-down processing, whereas P3a has a fronto-central scalp distribution, occurs earlier than P3b, and reflects the bottom-up capture of attention and orientation after an odd stimulus is presented. Different studies have

figure.head: 14 / 44 presentation
figure.figDesc: software of the NeuroScan NuAmps EEG amplifier and NeuroScan audio-video simulator (Stim II software): "CARDSORT," a version based on Berg and Grant, 1948[45]. The software allows us to adapt the experiment by choosing the number of trials and the rule-change conditions. In this experiment, the rule is modified after a number of correct responses, and this number changes randomly between six and nine trials, avoiding the prediction of a new sorting category.

understand the neurophysiological basis of EFs, assessed through the WCST, we will collect and analyze brain event-related potentials (ERPs). As we have previously described in detail in the section entitled "Neuroscientific Approach: Depression and measures of WCST," EFs are frequently compromised in people suffering from depression at distinct levels of analysis. Regarding brain components, P300 amplitude is decreased and P300 latency is prolonged under depression, which could be related to difficulties in set-shifting, memory update, executive attention, and working memory operations. In addition, we will explain the P3a and P3b components associated with bottom-up and top-down processing, respectively.

figure.head: 24 / 44 after
figure.figDesc: training to understand whether a reduction in N1 could be related to a decrease in P200 over frontal and central regions, increasing errors of discrimination and affecting inhibitory control. Furthermore, it will be important to explore mismatch negativity (MMN) in relation to the voluntary effort associated with cognitive switching, cognitive control, or response inhibition. The frontal component of MMN appears to be related to an increase in the number of perseverative errors in the WCST. Depression processing shows significant differences in the amplitude of MMN at frontal and frontocentral electrodes, and we need to understand better these processes. Moreover, we want to study a component associated with the ability to detect negative feedback or error. It is named "Error-related Negativity" (ERN). Depression has different effects on this brain component, which need to be clarified. The "correct response negativity" (CRN) and how both components could produce an alteration of P300. In this line, it could be interesting to understand the brain activation in "Switch-Negative Feedback" (Switch-NF), which requires more attention and inhibition, and the "Learn-Negative Feedback" (Lear-NF), which evokes distinct ERPs patterns at different brain regions and could be associated with perseverative and nonperseverative errors, having an effect on P2, solving problems, and decision making.

different brain components associated with executive deficits under depression: P3, P3a, P3b, P2, N1, MMN, ERN, CRN, Switch-NF, and Learn-NF; at different brain areas: frontal and prefrontal regions, central, parietal, posterior, temporal areas, and hemisphere (left, middle, and right), for each group (experimental group, active control group, and passive control group); and at three different moments: preintervention, postintervention, and three-month follow-up.

figure.head: Finally, to analyze
figure.figDesc: relationships between brain components and EFs (behavioral results), we will calculate Pearson correlation coefficients. Using the mean amplitude (locations depending on the brain component) and peak latency (location depending on the brain component) of the given brain component from difference waves.

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Outputs of the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)

row.cell: To perform this task, participants need to activate diverse domains and components of
executive functions. They must understand instructions, organize information, focus
on the principal card, plan an action, choose the matching card, consider the feedback,
infer the classification criteria, remember the rules, manipulate information, shift the
mind when the rule changes, update, and inhibit continuing to respond to a previous
rule. It is possible to check the enumeration and description of the outputs of the
WCST in the current publication and the supplementary material (Table 1, Additional

figure.figDesc: Besides, evoked potential may reflect differences in depressive subjects' brain functioning regarding diverse components. P300 is a positive deflection that occurs 200-500 ms after a stimulus. Its amplitude and latency are related to information processing, stimulus evaluation, categorization, decision-making, and working memory. P3 is frequently elicited in a task where the target stimuli are rarely presented among repetitive standard stimuli, and it is frequently modality independent.
figure.note: In addition, electroencephalographic studies have shown differential brain activity in depressive subjects. Spectral analysis that shows the power amplitudes of each band associated with brain mechanisms reports that alpha, beta, gamma, theta, and delta activity can work as biomarkers that allow us to differentiate between depressive and

figure.figDesc: ). The mismatching stimuli elicit a negative-going wave that frequently peaks between 160 and 220 ms at midline scalp sites. This MMN seems to reflect an automatic process that compares new stimuli to an auditory sensory memory of previous stimuli[60].However, some studies have demonstrated that MMN is associated not only with an automatic preattentive response to deviant auditory stimuli but also with voluntary effort related to attention switching or mental shift. Toyomaki and Kusumi et al.[61] found a correlation between low MMN amplitude and poor EFs performance in schizophrenia patients using a nonauditory task, the WCST, to assess EFs, specifically cognitive switching, and the Stroop test to assess cognitive control or response inhibition[61].MMN may receive some contribution from frontal sources. People with dorsolateral prefrontal cortex lesions showed reduced MMN amplitude. Toyomaki and Kusumi et al.[61] suggested that the frontal component of MMN might be associated with conscious perception of attention switching to stimulus change. In fact, they found a significant association with increased perseveration errors in the WCST. These perseverative errors can be explained by a lack of attention switch and/or mental set shift and difficulty of response inhibition (registered by Stroop Test). The authors suggested that the prefrontal cortex might work in connection with auditory areas in the temporal cortex, contributing to sensory perceptual processes for MMN generation and further higher-cognition processes [61]. Under depression, participants completing an auditory task show significant differences in the amplitude of MMN at frontal and frontocentral electrodes, which can be related to cognitive deficits associated with preattentive states, complex cognitive perceptual processes, and EFs [62-65]. However, further research is needed to understand the relationship between depression, executive functions, and MMN. Regarding the ability to detect negative feedback or error processing, conflict monitoring, information updates, mind shifts, and decision-making functions, another brain component has been extensively studied: error-related negativity (ERN), discovered by Falkenstein and Hohnsbein et al.[66]. This component refers to a negative-going deflection at frontal and central electrodes that peaks at 100 ms of error commission in simple decision tasks [60, 66, 67]. It happens after responding, and it is frequently followed by a positive deflection, associated with the evaluation of the erroneous response [68]. However, the role of error-related negativity in depression still needs to be clarified. Some studies have shown an effect of depression on ERN, registering more negative amplitudes in some cases, reduced amplitudes in other cases, or no differential effects between healthy and depressive participants [69, 70]. There are experiments showing that amplitudes of the CRN (correct response negativity) and the ERN, summate with stimulus-locked ERPs as the P300, showing altered response-related ERPs in depression that are not present [71]. Regarding the WCST, further research is needed to understand the contribution of this tool to assessing brain response-related components, although several studies have shown that the brain activation response to negative feedback (NF) is different at several stages of the WCST. Switch negative feedback (Switch-NF) requires more ), evoking distinct ERPs patterns on the frontal regions and nonfrontal brain regions. Perseverative errors appear to be related to a disruption in the frontal-extratiatal network, which is involved in the selection of visually relevant information. The absence of an extrastiate N1 component appears to temporarily precede a significant reduction in P2 over the right frontal region, while the ERPs pattern evoked by distractions or nonperseverative errors shows a different pattern of activation. They occur in more central and frontal areas, and enhancements of P2 are registered during distractions. This fact can be associated with a loss of inhibitory control of interfering stimuli
figure.note: attention and inhibition than learn negative feedback (Learn-NF), and it is associated with different evoked potentials (EPs) [72] and distinct errors (perseverative errors and nonperseverative errors

div.head: Conflicts of interest
div.p: The author declare that do not have conflicts of interest.

div.head: Ethical approval
div.p: The present experiment and the whole project will be conducted in accordance with The Declaration of Helsinki [99]. It will be presented to the Ethics Committee of the Centre designated for the development of the project for protocol approval, and all participants will sign a written informed consent and will be informed of their right to cease participation in the study at any time.

div.head: Consent to participate
div.p: Informed consent to participate in the study will be obtained from all participants.

div.head: Consent to publication
div.p: Informed consent to publication will be obtained from participants.

div.head: Availability of data and materials
div.p: The data that support the findings of this study are openly available in the [
